p: Because willows are important early‐season flower resources for pollinators (Formica et al., 2014; Moquet, Mayer, Michez, Wathelet, & Jacquemart, 2015) altitudinal migration of males may also negatively affect pollination regimes of resident alpine wildflower species. At high altitudes and latitudes, Salix acts as a magnet species, drawing pollinators away from the more diminutive floral displays of tundra plants (Lara‐Romero et al., 2016; Mosquin & Martin, 1967). Here we investigate the potential for willow shrubification of alpine meadows to reduce reproductive success of resident wildflowers due to HP via pollinator sharing, focusing on the skypilot, P. viscosum, an obligate outcrosser that depends primarily on bumble bees for pollination (Galen, 1996).
